Brelatioeass in the Stea-
Select SO uniform individuals of Tubularia, and cut off hydranth
and a short piece of distal stem, as before. From the distal (hydranth)
end of each stem cut a piece mm. long, takvng care not to confuse the
orientation of the pieces. Divide them into two lots of l5, A and B. 
Fasten the pieces of the A lot wide their distal ends all on the same i
side, in a fingerbowl of sea water. Ligate each of the lot pieces
in the middle, by tying a thread firmly around it, and orient them
similarly in a fingerbowl of sea water. Cover both fingerbowls and
place them in the sink to be kept cool. Change water regularly.
Cn the third day record the number of individuals in A which
show regeneration on their proximal ends, and the number which show
regeneration distally. Do the same for the ligated lot individuals.
Esmpared with the lot in which the two ends have been isolated by
Ligature, do the A lot show any indication of a dominance-suppression
relationship of the two ends? Which end is dominant? (Barth '58)

THB, or nislicsnusi .
There are two phases of embryology in the Hydrozoa. Characteris~
pically, a long series of asexual reproductions, by budding and other
methods, is punctuated at irregular intervals by alternation with
isolated examples of sexual reproduction. this alternation of genera- 
tion is closely paralleled by an alternation of form, since the pro-
duction of zygotes is usually accomplished by medusae, and the pro~
luqtion of buds by polyps. In some hydrozoa no medusa~form is known,
in others no polyp-form is known, and there are all stages between.
She hydrozoa available at Woods hole illustrate well the variability in
structure of the medusa~state. ihe best example of a complete medusa
with a degenerate polyp stage is idealized jelly~fish Gonionemus,
but it is unfortunately now nearly extinct at Woods Hole. The genera
picked for study are arranged in the order of diminishing completeness
ei'the medusa form, the first having free~swimming medusae and the
last mere sporosacs. The utter degeneration of the medusa-form is
illustrated by the familiar Hydra. 
Because of seasonal variations and unpredictable fluctuations
in the Coelenterate fauna, some of the material desoribed~may not be
available, and the order of study will have to be announced.
heugainvillae (July and August)
The gdnophores are borne singly or in clusters on the main stem
ind branches. New buds destined to become medusae are scattered
irregularly throughout the colony, there being no arrangement according
to age. Examine buds that show successive stages of development, and
find out how a medusa is formed.
When all of its parts except the sex organs are fully formed,
the medusa breaks loose mid swims away, living l~2 months. Its struc~
ture is diagrammatic. Find a well~developed specimen and identify its
nmnubrium, radial and circular canals, velum, 4 groups of marginal
tentacles and eyespots. These medusae gradually form eggs and sperm
but the embryos do not develop inside them.
